front.title: Performance Measurement Using RFC 6374 for Segment Routing Networks with MPLS Data Plane

abstract.t: Segment Routing (SR) leverages the source routing paradigm. RFC 6374 specifies protocol mechanisms to enable the efficient and accurate measurement of packet loss, one-way and two-way delay, as well as related metrics such as delay variation in MPLS networks. This document utilizes these mechanisms for Performance Delay and Loss Measurements in SR networks with MPLS data plane (SR-MPLS), for both SR-MPLS links and end-to-end SR-MPLS paths including Policies. In addition, this document defines Return Path TLV and Block Number TLV extensions for RFC 6374.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Segment Routing (SR) leverages the source routing paradigm and greatly simplifies network operations for Software Defined Networks (SDNs). SR is applicable to both Multiprotocol Label Switching (SR-MPLS) and IPv6 (SRv6) data planes. SR takes advantage of the Equal-Cost Multipaths (ECMPs) between source and transit nodes, between transit nodes and between transit and destination nodes. SR Policies as defined in are used to steer traffic through a specific, user-defined paths using a stack of Segments. Built-in SR Performance Measurement (PM) is one of the essential requirements to provide Service Level Agreements (SLAs).

specifies protocol mechanisms to enable the efficient and accurate measurement of performance metrics in MPLS networks using query and response messages. specifies mechanisms for sending and processing out-of-band responses over an UDP return path when receiving query messages. These mechanisms are also well-suited in SR-MPLS networks.

This document utilizes the mechanisms defined in for Performance Delay and Loss Measurements in SR-MPLS networks, for both SR-MPLS links and end-to-end SR-MPLS paths including Policies. In addition, this document defines Return Path TLV and Block Number TLV extensions for .

section.title: Reference Topology
section.t: In the reference topology shown in Figure 1, the querier node R1 initiates a query message and the responder node R3 sends a response message for the query message received. The response message is sent back to the querier node R1 in-band on the same path (same set of links and nodes) or a different path in the reverse direction.

SR is enabled with MPLS data plane on nodes R1 and R3. The nodes R1 and R3 may be directly connected via a link enabled with MPLS (Section 2.9.1 of ) or a Point-to-Point (P2P) SR-MPLS path . The link may be a physical interface, virtual link, or Link Aggregation Group (LAG) , or Layer-2 LAG bundle member link. The SR-MPLS path may be an SR-MPLS Policy on node R1 (called head-end) with destination to node R3 (called tail-end).

section.title: Overview
section.t: As described in Section 2.9.1 of , the query and response messages flow over the MPLS Generic Associated Channel (G-ACh). These query and response messages contain G-ACh Label (GAL) (value 13, with S=1). The GAL is followed by an Associated Channel Header (ACH), where Channel Type identifies the message type, and the message payload following the ACH as shown in Figure 2.

For one-way, two-way and round-trip delay and delay variation measurement in SR-MPLS networks, the procedures defined in Section 2.4 and Section 2.5 of are used. For transmit and receive packet loss measurement in SR-MPLS networks, the procedures defined in Section 2.2 and Section 2.6 of are used.
For Performance Measurement in SR-MPLS networks, the query and response messages defined in are sent as following:

list.t: For delay measurement, the query messages are sent for the data traffic flow under measurement by the querier, and are used to collect the transmit and receive timestamps to measure the delay experienced by the data traffic flowing on the SR-MPLS links and end-to-end SR-MPLS Policies.

For loss measurement, the query messages are sent for the data traffic flow under measurement by the querier, and are used to collect the transmit traffic counters and the receive traffic counters (e.g. for traffic received on the incoming link for the link loss or on the incoming Path Segment Identifier (PSID) for the end-to-end SR-MPLS path loss) to measure the packet loss experienced by the data traffic flowing on the SR-MPLS links and end-to-end SR-MPLS Policies.

section.t: The Performance Measurements (PM) for SR-MPLS links can be used to compute extended Traffic Engineering (TE) metrics for delay and loss as described in Section 10 and advertised in the network using the routing protocol extensions defined in , , and .
The In-Situ Operations, Administration, and Maintenance (IOAM) mechanisms for SR-MPLS defined in are used to record OAM information in the packets, and are outside the scope of this document.

section.title: Query Message for SR-MPLS Links and Policies
Query Message for SR-MPLS Links
section.t: A query message as shown in Figure 2 is sent over the SR-MPLS links for both delay and loss measurement using the procedures described in . For SR-MPLS links, the TTL value is set to 1 in the SR-MPLS header.

section.title: Query Message for SR-MPLS Policies
section.t: A query message for an end-to-end SR-MPLS Policy measurement contains SR-MPLS label stack , with the G-ACh Label (GAL) at the bottom of the stack (with S=1) as shown in Figure 3. For SR-MPLS Policies, the TTL value is set to 255 in the SR-MPLS header.

figure.title: Example Query Message Header for an End-to-end SR-MPLS Policy

section.t: The SR-MPLS label stack can be empty (similar to as shown in Figure 2) to indicate Implicit NULL label case.

For SR-MPLS Policy performance measurement, in order to ensure that the query message is processed by the intended responder, Destination Address TLV (Type 129) MAY be sent in the query message. The responder only returns Success in Control Code if it is the intended destination for the query. Otherwise, it MUST return 0x15: Error - Invalid Destination Node Identifier .

section.title: Response Message for SR-MPLS Links and Policies
One-way Measurement Mode
section.t: In one-way measurement mode defined in Section 2.4 of , the querier can receive "out-of-band" responses by properly setting the UDP Return Object (URO) TLV in the query message. The URO TLV (Type=131) is defined in and includes the UDP-Destination-Port and IP Address. When the querier sets an IP address in the URO TLV, the response is sent to that IP address as destination. In addition, the "control code" in the query message is set to "out-of-band response requested".

In one-way delay measurement mode, as per Reference Topology, the timestamps T1 and T2 are collected by the query and response messages. Both these timestamps are used to measure one-way delay as (T2 - T1).

section.title: Two-way Measurement Mode
section.t: In two-way measurement mode defined in Section 2.4 of , the response messages are sent back to the querier in-band on the same path (same set of links and nodes) in the reverse direction. In this case, the "control code" in the query message is set to "in-band response requested".
For SR-MPLS links, the response message is sent back on the same incoming link where the query message is received.

For end-to-end SR-MPLS paths, the responder needs to transmit the response message (with format shown in Figure 3) on a specific reverse SR-MPLS path . The querier can request in the query message to the responder to send the response message back on a given reverse path using an SR-MPLS Segment List sub-TLV in the Return Path TLV defined in this document.

In two-way delay measurement mode, as per Reference Topology, all timestamps T1, T2, T3, and T4 are collected by the query and response messages. All four timestamps are used to measure two-way delay as ((T4 - T1) - (T3 - T2)).

section.title: Loopback Measurement Mode
section.t: The Loopback measurement mode defined in Section 2.8 of can be used to measure round-trip delay for a bidirectional circular SR-MPLS path . The query messages in this case carry the return path label stack as part of the MPLS header. The GAL is carried at the bottom of the label stack (with S=1).
As the responder does not process the query messages and generate response messages, the Loopback Request object (Type 3) is not required for an end-to-end SR-MPLS path.
In loopback delay measurement mode, as per Reference Topology, the timestamps T1 and T4 are collected by the query messages. Both these timestamps are used to measure round-trip delay as (T4 - T1).

section.title: Delay Measurement Message Format
section.t: As defined in , MPLS DM query and response messages use Associated Channel Header (ACH) (value 0x000C for delay measurement) , which identifies the message type, and the message payload following the ACH. For both SR-MPLS links and end-to-end SR-MPLS Policies, the same MPLS DM ACH value is used.
The DM message payload as defined in Section 3.2 of is used for SR-MPLS delay measurement, for both SR-MPLS links and end-to-end SR-MPLS Policies.

section.title: Timestamps
section.t: The Section 3.4 of defines timestamp format that can be used for delay measurement. The IEEE 1588 Precision Time Protocol (PTP) timestamp format is used by default as described in Appendix A of . The timestamping in hardware is recommended in SR networks.

section.title: Loss Measurement
section.t: The LM protocol can perform two distinct kinds of loss measurement as described in Section 2.9.8 of .

list.t: In inferred mode, LM will measure the loss of specially generated test messages in order to infer the approximate data plane loss level. Inferred mode LM provides only approximate loss accounting.
In direct mode, LM will directly measure data plane packet loss. Direct mode LM provides perfect loss accounting, but may require hardware support.

section.t: The Path Segment Identifier (PSID) carried in the received data packet for the traffic flow under measurement can be used for accounting received traffic on the on the egress node of the SR-MPLS Policy. For direct mode, the PSID in the received query message as shown in Figure 4 can be used to associate the receive traffic counter on the responder for the end-to-end SR-MPLS Policy. Different values of PSID can be used to measure packet loss per SR-MPLS Policy, per Candidate Path or per Segment List of the SR Policy.

figure.title: Example With Path Segment Identifier for SR-MPLS Policy

section.title: Loss Measurement Message Format
section.t: As defined in , MPLS LM query and response messages use Associated Channel Header (ACH) (value 0x000A for direct loss measurement or value 0x000B for inferred loss measurement), which identifies the message type, and the message payload following the ACH. For both SR-MPLS links and end-to-end SR-MPLS Policies, the same MPLS LM ACH value is used.
The LM message payload as defined in Section 3.1 of is used for SR-MPLS loss measurement, for both SR-MPLS links and end-to-end SR-MPLS Policies.

section.title: Combined Loss/Delay Measurement Message Format
section.t: As defined in , Combined DM+LM query and response messages use Associated Channel Header (ACH) (value 0x000D for direct loss and delay measurement or value 0x000E for inferred loss and delay measurement), which identifies the message type, and the message payload following the ACH. For both SR-MPLS links and end-to-end SR-MPLS Policies, the same MPLS DM+LM ACH value is used.
The message payload as defined in Section 3.3 of is used for SR-MPLS combined delay and loss measurement, for both SR-MPLS links and end-to-end SR-MPLS Policies.

section.title: Return Path TLV Extension
section.t: In two-way measurement mode, the responder needs to send the response message on a specific return path. The querier can request in the query message to the responder to send a response message back on a given return path (e.g. co-routed SR-MPLS path for two-way measurement). This way the responder avoids creating and maintaining extra dynamic SR states for the return paths.
In one-way measurement mode, the querier address may not be reachable via IP route from the responder. The querier in this case can send its reachability path information to the responder.

defines DM and LM query messages that can include one or more optional TLVs. New TLV Type (TBA2) is defined in this document for Return Path to carry return path information in the query messages (in the payload). The format of the Return Path TLV is shown in Figure 5:

The Return Path TLV is a Mandatory TLV Type. The querier MUST only insert one Return Path TLV in the query message. The responder that supports this TLV, MUST only process the first Return Path TLV and ignore the other Return Path TLVs if present. The responder also MUST NOT add Return Path TLV in the response message. The Reserved field MUST be set to 0 and MUST be ignored on the receive side.

section.title: Return Path Sub-TLV Extension
section.t: The Return Path TLV contains a Sub-TLV to carry the return path. The format of the Segment List Sub-TLV is shown in Figure 6. The Label entries MUST be in network order. The Segment List Sub-TLV in the Return Path TLV can be one of the following Types:

list.t: Type (value 1): SR-MPLS Label Stack of the Return Path

figure.title: Segment List Sub-TLV in Return Path TLV

section.t: An SR-MPLS Label Stack Sub-TLV may carry only Binding SID of the Return SR-MPLS Policy.

The Return Path TLV MUST carry only one Return Path Sub-TLV. The responder that supports this Sub-TLV, MUST only process the first Return Path Sub-TLV and ignore the other Return Path Sub-TLVs if present. The responder also MUST send response message back on the return path specified in the Return Path Sub-TLV. The Reserved field MUST be set to 0 and MUST be ignored on the receive side.

section.title: Block Number TLV Extension
section.t: The loss measurement using Alternate-Marking method defined in requires coloring the data traffic flow under measurement. To be able to correlate the transmit and receive traffic counters of the matching color, the Block Number (or color) of the traffic counters is carried by the query and response messages for loss measurement.

defines query and response messages that can include one or more optional TLVs. New TLV Type (value TBA1) is defined in this document to carry the Block Number (8-bit) of the traffic counters in the query and response messages for loss measurement. The format of the Block Number TLV is shown in Figure 7:

The Block Number TLV is a Mandatory TLV Type. The querier MUST only insert one Block Number TLV in the query message to identify the Block Number for the traffic counters in the forward direction. The responder that supports this TLV, MUST only inert one Block Number TLV in the response message to identify the Block Number for the traffic counters in the reverse direction. The responder also MUST return the first Block Number TLV from the query message and ignore the other Block Number TLVs if present. The R Flag MUST be clear in the query message and set in the response message. The Reserved field MUST be set to 0 and MUST be ignored on the receive side.

section.title: Performance Measurement for P2MP SR-MPLS Policies
section.t: The Point-to-Multipoint (P2MP) SR-MPLS path that originates from a root node terminates on multiple destinations called leaf nodes (e.g. P2MP SR-MPLS Policy ).

The procedures for delay and loss measurement described in this document for end-to-end P2P SR-MPLS Policies are also equally applicable to the P2MP SR-MPLS Policies. The procedure for one-way measurement is defined as following:

list.t: The querier root node sends query messages using the Tree-SID defined in for the P2MP SR-MPLS Policy as shown in Figure 8. The query messages may contain the replication SID as defined in .

Each responder leaf node sends its node address in the "Source Address" TLV (Type 130) in the response messages. This TLV allows the querier root node to identify the responder leaf nodes of the P2MP SR-MPLS Policy.
The P2MP root node measures the delay and loss performance for each P2MP leaf node individually.

figure.title: Example Query with Tree-SID for SR-MPLS Policy

section.t: The considerations for two-way and loopback measurement modes for P2MP SR-MPLS Policy (e.g. for co-routed bidirectional SR-MPLS path) are outside the scope of this document.

section.title: ECMP for SR-MPLS Policies
section.t: An SR-MPLS Policy can have ECMPs between the source and transit nodes, between transit nodes and between transit and destination nodes. Usage of Anycast SID by an SR-MPLS Policy can result in ECMP paths via transit nodes part of that Anycast group. The query and response messages need to be sent to traverse different ECMP paths to measure delay of each of the ECMP path of an SR-MPLS Policy.

Forwarding plane has various hashing functions available to forward packets on specific ECMP paths. For SR-MPLS Policy, sweeping of entropy label values can be used in query and response messages to take advantage of the hashing function in forwarding plane to influence the ECMP path taken by them.
The considerations for loss measurement for different ECMP paths of an SR-MPLS Policy are outside the scope of this document.

section.title: SR-MPLS Link Extended TE Metrics Advertisements
section.t: The extended TE metrics for SR-MPLS link delay and loss can be computed using the procedures described in this document and advertised in the routing domain as follows:

list.t: For OSPF, ISIS, and BGP-LS, protocol extensions defined in , , and are used, respectively for advertising the extended TE link metrics in the network.
The extended TE link delay and loss metrics are advertised for Layer-2 LAG bundle member links in OSPF and ISIS using the same mechanisms defined in and , respectively.
The advertised delay-variance metric is Packet Delay Variation (PDV) and is computed as described in Section 4.2 of .
The extended TE link one-way delay metrics can also be computed using the two-way and round-trip delay values by dividing the values by 2.

section.title: Backwards Compatibility
section.t: The procedures defined in this document are backwards compatible with the procedures defined in at both querier and responder. If the responder does not support the new Mandatory TLV Types defined in this document, it MUST return Error 0x17: Unsupported Mandatory TLV Object as per .

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: This document describes the procedures for performance delay and loss measurement for SR-MPLS networks, for both SR-MPLS links and end-to-end SR-MPLS Policies using the mechanisms defined in and . This document does not introduce any additional security considerations other than those covered in , , , , and .
